headline: Wells shed its asset cap — but it isn't clear why
summary: The first-of-its-kind growth restriction established a new precedent for how regulators can address a broken bank culture. With scant information about why the cap was lifted, the action provides little clarity on what Wells did right — or what the Fed did wrong.

raw.headline: Wells shed its asset cap — but it isn't clear why
raw.summary: The first-of-its-kind growth restriction established a new precedent for how regulators can address a broken bank culture. With scant information about why the cap was lifted, the action provides little clarity on what Wells did right — or what the Fed did wrong.

headline: Wells Fargo CEO goes from fixer to builder as regulators lift punishments
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf knows he has a reputation for sternness, but he said that when the bank was finally freed of a $1.95 trillion asset cap by regulators on Tuesday, he became emotional.  "Everyone thinks that I'm this tough, tough person ... but it's been so long in the making, it's impacted so many people so negatively," Scharf said.  Scharf, 60, took the helm at Wells Fargo in 2019, vowing to repair its deeply entrenched problems from a fake-accounts scandal that erupted in 2016.

headline: What's in Wells Fargo's future after the Fed's asset cap lift?
summary: The Federal Reserve lifted Wells Fargo's (WFC) $1.95 trillion asset cap this week.  Chris Whalen, chairman of Whalen Global Advisors, explains why Wells Fargo's focus is shifting toward retail banking and away from wholesale lending. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here.

headline: Why Wells Fargo Shares Are Up Today
summary: Regulatory caps that limited growth have been lifted, freeing Wells Fargo to pursue new business.  Wells Fargo (NYSE: WFC) is out of the penalty box, more than seven years after regulators put limits on growth in response to a fake-accounts scandal.  It has been a lost decade for Wells Fargo.

headline: Wells Fargo shares hit three-month high as Fed ends growth freeze
summary: (Reuters) -Shares of Wells Fargo rose more than 2% on Wednesday after the U.S. Federal Reserve lifted a longstanding cap on its assets, marking a crucial milestone in the bank's push to rebuild its reputation and grow further.  The fourth-largest U.S. bank was operating under a $1.95-trillion asset cap mandated by the Fed in 2018 aimed at restricting its growth until regulators deemed it had fixed its problems dating back to the 2016 fake-accounts scandal.  Speaking in an interview with CNBC, CEO Charlie Scharf said he wants to increase dividend payouts and will focus on growth in credit cards and investment banking divisions.

Speaking in an interview with CNBC, CEO Charlie Scharf said he wants to increase dividend payouts and will focus on growth in credit cards and investment banking divisions.
